See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 1 shows the schematic implementation of one LSP sensor, attached to aluminium shell.
This shell is 7 cm in height and 20 cm in width.
The arm was instructed to move along X axis above the surface of LSP sensor.
During its motion, the input EM wave was supplied from a fixed location on LSP sensor while the output was obtained at several locations starting from a \(0 mm) to A \(20 mm).
The sensor was curve-linear, but has a steeper slope on one side from the midpoint \(M =10 mm).
More about this can be obtained in our associated publication \[10].
See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 2 shows the schematic implementation of  LSP sensor and lead waveguide.
The LSP is attached to one block while the waveguide laid \(spread) from the center of the sensor perpendicular to block's length.
The adjacent concrete block was moved from close to far from the first block.
The process of concrete blocks separation, i.e movement of a second block from 0 cm \(no separation) to 9 cm  was monitored.
The input was supplied at a fixed location above LSP sensor, whereas the output was extracted at several locations above the surface of the waveguide along X direction as shown in figure \[10].
See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]

Figure 3 shows signals of scattered parameter \(S21)  i.e. output transmission or surface wave magnitude obtained throughout the journey, starting from baseline \(edge of the sensor), point a \(0 mm - outside copper) until point A \(20 mm - outside copper) for an input frequency range of 3 GHz to 7 GHz.
It was observed that the magnitude of the resonance peak increased gradually from starting point to mid-point \(M), then gradually dropped as the robotic-arm moved further from point M.
See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
The signal is always a qualitative information useful for non-ACM engineering groups such as optics, physics, biology, etc.
However, for ACM engineering groups, a more mathematical/ statistical quantitative method such as a Root Mean Square Deviation \(RMSD) is additionally adopted for the obtained signals \[10, 15].
Figure 4 shows the formula and the application procedure.
The RMSD is represented as a percentage frequency function, which can increase or decrease or can be unstable with unpredictable fluctuations.
This RMSD is considered as a sensitivity measure of smart materials used for engineering monitoring \[6, 11].
5. See figure in Figures section.
\[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 5 shows the sensitivity \(RMSD) of surface wave output as the robotic arm moved over the top of the curve-linear shell \(and LSP sensor).
The shape of the graph is similar to the shape of the shell, which was slightly steep on one side.
6. See figure in Figures section. \[Click to Enlarge]
Figure 6 shows the sensitivity of the surface wave output above the waveguide, as the robotic arm moved over the top of linear waveguide.
The increase of separation between the concrete blocks increased the RMSD.
The signals are not shown here, but are available in the associated journal \[10].
However, the RMSD graph shows more meaningful interpretation/ proportionality compared to raw signals.
